[AC spectrum of the almost Mathieu operator]
The absolutely continuous spectrum of the almost Mathieu operator

Artur Avila

CNRS UMR 7599, Laboratoire de Probabilites et Modeles aleatoires

Universite Pierre et Marie Curie-Boite courrier 188

75252-Paris Cedex 05, France

IMPA, Estrada Dona Castorina 110, Rio de Janeiro, 22460-320,
Brazil
artur@math.sunysb.edu

We prove that the spectrum of the almost Mathieu operator is absolutely
continuous if and only if the coupling is subcritical.  This settles
Problem 6 of Barry Simon's list of Schrodinger operator problems
for the twenty-first century.

Introduction

This work is concerned with the almost Mathieu operator

defined on   (H u)_n=u_n+1+u_n-1+2 (2[+n ])
u_n where  is the coupling,
is the
frequency and  is the phase.  This is the most studied
quasiperiodic
Schrodinger operator, arising naturally as a physical model (see
for a recent historical account and for the physics background).

We are interested in the decomposition of the spectral measures in atomic
(corresponding to point spectrum),
singular continuous and absolutely continuous parts.  Our main result is the
following.

thm

The spectral measures of the almost Mathieu operator
are absolutely continuous if and only if .

Background

Background

Singularity of the spectral measures for  had been
previously established (it follows from,,
).  Thus the Main Theorem reduces to showing absolute continuity
of the spectral measures for , which is Problem 6 of
Barry Simon's list.

We recall the history of this problem (following).
Aubry-Andre conjectured the following dependence on  of the
nature of the spectral measures:

(Supercritical regime)
For , spectral measures are pure point,

(Subcritical regime) For , spectral measures are
absolutely continuous.
A measure-theoretical version of this conjecture was proved by Jitomirskaya
: it holds for almost every  and .  Problem 6 of
, which was formulated after (and was likely partially motivated
by) is entirely
about showing that, in the subcritical regime, this
conjecture is in fact true for all  and .

The description of the supercritical regime
turns out to be wrong as stated.  More precisely, for generic
there can never be point spectrum,,
whatever  and  are chosen, and for every  there is
a generic set of  for which there is similarly no point
spectrum.  Thus the result of is essentially the best
possible in the supercritical regime (one can still look for more
optimal conditions on the parameters, which can be sometimes useful for
other purposes, see and).

There was some hope that the description of
the subcritical regime was actually correct as stated, since the work
of Last, Gesztesy-Simon (see also
Last-Simon)

established that there are absolutely continuous components (of some spectral
measures) for every  and  (belief in the conjecture was
however not unanimous, due to lack of any further evidence for generic
).

established that there are absolutely continuous components (of some spectral
measures) for every  and  (belief in the conjecture was
however not unanimous, due to lack of any further evidence for generic
).

Two key advances happened recently.
In, the problem was settled for almost every
and every ,
and soon later, in it was settled for every
(to be precise, for every  that can not be dealt with by
,) and almost every .
Those two results are based on quite independent methods, a ramification of
the fact that, as usually happens in quasiperiodic problems,
several aspects of the operators do depend qualitatively on the arithmetics.

Outline

Our proof of the complete conjecture splits into two parts that do not
interact.  The arithmetic properties of , more precisely whether
it is "well approximated by rational numbers" or not, will decide which
of the two methods will be applied.

Let  be the continued fraction approximants to
and let
n
q_n+1 q_n.
For our problem, the key distinction is whether  (the
subexponential regime) or  (the exponential regime).

The subexponential regime

In, Eliasson introduced a sophisticated KAM scheme that allowed
him to study the entire spectrum of one-dimensional quasiperiodic
Schrodinger operators in the perturbative regime.  Applied to the
almost Mathieu operator, his results imply that, for frequencies
satisfying the usual Diophantine condition , that is
, and for
sufficiently small (depending on ), the spectral
measures of the almost Mathieu operator are absolutely continuous.

In, a non-perturbative method was introduced that, when
applied to the almost Mathieu operator, gives sharp estimates through the
whole subcritical regime for .  Absolute continuity of the
spectral measures was then concluded by showing that, after an appropriate
"change of coordinates", the smallness requirements of the
KAM scheme of Eliasson were satisfied.

In, a non-perturbative method was introduced that, when
applied to the almost Mathieu operator, gives sharp estimates through the
whole subcritical regime for .  Absolute continuity of the
spectral measures was then concluded by showing that, after an appropriate
"change of coordinates", the smallness requirements of the
KAM scheme of Eliasson were satisfied.

In order to extend the conclusions of to the subexponential
regime ,
there are two main difficulties.  The first is that some
key estimates of break down in this setting (essentially for not
achieving exponential decay of Fourier coefficients which is needed to
address the entire  regime).
The second is that the "easy path" consisting of
reducing to a KAM scheme is out of reach.  Indeed, the expected
limit of the KAM method is the Brjuno condition  on , but this is still stronger than
.  Thus a novel, more robust, approach to
absolute continuity of the spectral measures will need to be implemented.

We notice that the discussion in the subexponential regime yields
significant information which goes beyond the absolute continuity of the
spectral measures (see for instance Remark  for an example),
and can also be applied to the more general context considered in(see  and ).

The exponential regime

In the exponential regime, our approach will be to show that each
exponentially close rational approximation
gives a lower bound on the mass
of the absolutely continuous component of a spectral measure, and that
this lower bound converges to the total mass of the spectral measure.

In the exponential regime, our approach will be to show that each
exponentially close rational approximation
gives a lower bound on the mass
of the absolutely continuous component of a spectral measure, and that
this lower bound converges to the total mass of the spectral measure.

In, this approach was used to prove absolute continuity of the
integrated density of states, which is the average of the
spectral measures over different  (absolute continuity of the
spectral measures for almost every  is obtained as a consequence of
this result, by applying and).
The key point of
was to compare averages of the spectral measures (restricted to a large
part of the spectrum) over long sequences
with the corresponding objects for
the periodic operator obtained by replacing  with .
In such approach, we clearly lose control of individual phases, and one can
not hope to recover a result for every phase by an abstract scheme such as
Kotani's.

Here we will describe a key novel mechanism of "cancellation" among
different phases (which we hope will find wider applicability).  We show
that an abnormally small (compared with the
total mass) absolutely continuous component for any  implies the
existence of an abnormally large absolutely continuous component for some
.  The latter possibility giving a contradiction,
we conclude that all spectral measures have approximately the correct size.

Let us mention that the description of the critical regime at this point is
quite accurate but not complete.  One conjectures
(it is explicit in) that for , for every  and
the spectral measures are singular continuous.
This is proved for every  in the exponential regime and every
(Gordon's Lemma,,),
almost every  and  (),
and it is currently known to hold for every  and
almost every  ().
See also for a recent discussion
including further evidence for the conjecture.

Let us mention that the description of the critical regime at this point is
quite accurate but not complete.  One conjectures
(it is explicit in) that for , for every  and
the spectral measures are singular continuous.
This is proved for every  in the exponential regime and every
(Gordon's Lemma,,),
almost every  and  (),
and it is currently known to hold for every  and
almost every  ().
See also for a recent discussion
including further evidence for the conjecture.

Quasiperiodic Schrodinger operators
Though this work is dedicated to the almost Mathieu operator, several of our
techniques apply to a more general class of
quasiperiodic Schrodinger operators, where the cosine in
() is replaced by an arbitrary real analytic periodic
function of the circle.
Though for such operators, we no longer have a sharp phase transition, it
still makes sense to focus on the characterization and understanding
of the regions in the parameters space (including the energy) exhibiting
subcritical, critical and supercritical behavior.

Much recent work has been
developed regarding the "supercritical" regime
(characterized, dynamically, by
positive Lyapunov exponent), especially (but not always)
with Diophantine frequencies
(,,,).  On the other hand,
some ongoing research (mostly still unwritten, but including
and joint works with Fayad and Krikorian) are dedicated towards the
theory of the "subcritical" regime
(conjectured in to be
characterized, dynamically, by almost reducibility),
hopefully without arithmetic restrictions.  Some information on
the intermediate "critical" regime can be obtained as a consequence of
these developments (used in conjunction with
renormalization techniques such as) as well.

Much recent work has been
developed regarding the "supercritical" regime
(characterized, dynamically, by
positive Lyapunov exponent), especially (but not always)
with Diophantine frequencies
(,,,).  On the other hand,
some ongoing research (mostly still unwritten, but including
and joint works with Fayad and Krikorian) are dedicated towards the
theory of the "subcritical" regime
(conjectured in to be
characterized, dynamically, by almost reducibility),
hopefully without arithmetic restrictions.  Some information on
the intermediate "critical" regime can be obtained as a consequence of
these developments (used in conjunction with
renormalization techniques such as) as well.

Our results in this paper extend partially to this more general setting and
are an important part of the "subcritical program" (one of the goals of
which is to prove pure absolutely continuous spectrum in full generality).
It is important to note that the division of the
analysis into subexponential and exponential parts is still relevant,
with new techniques becoming available precisely when
.  This shows that the extension of the results offrom the usual Diophantine condition to the weaker
subexponential condition plays
an equally important role in the more general setting as well.  Fortunately,
the subexponential part of this work extends fully to the more general
setting, see .

On the other hand, the analysis of the exponential regime here is still
heavily bound by precise estimates which are only available for the
almost Mathieu operator, and a different analytic approach will need to be
developed to compensate for this.  However, we note that the "cancellation
technique" we describe in this paper, which is the only tool available for
deducing pure absolutely continuous spectrum for every phase in the
case of very Liouvillean frequencies, is robust enough to be applied in the
more general setting once such difficulties are overcome.

Acknowledgments: I would like to thank Svetlana Jitomirskaya and David
Damanik for our joint work on and, which form the
basis on which this work is built on, and for several helpful suggestions
regarding the writing of this paper.  This research was partially conducted
during the period the author served as a Clay Research Fellow.

Corona estimates

Given a non-zero vector , it is easy to find a matrix with first
column  that belongs to .  We just have to solve an equation
of the type , and it is trivial to get estimates on the size of the
solutions.  If  depends holomorphically of a parameter, to obtain a
holomorphic solution of the same problem with good estimates is much more
challenging, and it is related to the famous Corona Theorem of Carleson
.

The Corona Theorem states that if  and
,  are bounded holomorphic

such that .

pointwise then the

If instead of functions of the disk one considers functions of an annulus
, the conclusion of the Corona Theorem (with
the Uchiyama estimates) is
still valid, and is a consequence of the disk version (because the annulus
is uniformized by the disk and has amenable fundamental group).

The following is an equivalent convenient formulation of the case  of

The subexponential regime

The approach to the subexponential regime centers around the notion of
quantitative duality, first developed in: almost localization
estimates for the dual operator yield information on the
Fourier series of a "conjugacy" to constant.  The almost localization
estimate gives exponential decay away from "resonant" sites, but this does
not ensure convergence for all energies (for generic energies, it is
actually divergent).  Still, the estimates yield a good control
of the dynamics.

Though several aspects of the basic scheme of adapt without
difficulties to our weaker conditions, it is clear that
some of the estimates in lose exponential control of the decay
of Fourier coefficients, and hence are too weak to deal with the small
denominators arising in the regime  (the fight between the decay of
Fourier coefficients and the small denominators happens when we need to
solve the cohomological equation with small error).  This is overcome by the

Though several aspects of the basic scheme of adapt without
difficulties to our weaker conditions, it is clear that
some of the estimates in lose exponential control of the decay
of Fourier coefficients, and hence are too weak to deal with the small
denominators arising in the regime  (the fight between the decay of
Fourier coefficients and the small denominators happens when we need to
solve the cohomological equation with small error).  This is overcome by the

systematic use of estimates in a definite strip for the truncated
"conjugacies".  We then need to relate the control of the dynamics
with absolutely continuous spectrum (as described in the introduction,
invokes the KAM approach at this point, which we can not do).
We have good estimates on cocycle
growth in terms of the resonant character of the dual phase, and
bounds on cocycle growth yield upper
bounds on the spectral measures.  We still need estimates connecting the
"parametrization by dual phase" with the "parametrization by
energy"Each energy usually (almost everywhere)
corresponds to finitely many dual phases, but we have not been able to rule
out (and it is not even heuristically clear that this should be the case,
see footnote 11 of)
that for some exceptional set of energies there could be
uncountably many ones.  This is closely related to the
coexistence of both point and singular continuous spectrum for the dual
model.  Happily for us, the exceptional set is very small (with Hausdorff
dimension zero)., which is done
through a third parametrization, by fibered rotation number.

Another interpretation of the proof is that we give some Holder
control (in certain scales, we do not actually show full Holder
continuity here) on the spectral measures, while showing that the
support of the singular part has Hausdorff dimension zero (with good
coverings at the right scales to match the other estimate).

A generalization
This section can be ignored if one is only
interested in the proof of the Main Theorem.

Let  be analytic and let
be the
quasiperiodic Schrodinger operator given by
.  The almost Mathieu
operator corresponds to the special case  for some .

As for the almost Mathieu case, the spectral properties of
are intimately connected with the
Schrodinger cocycles , where
, and several key
notions have identical development, including spectral measures ,
-functions  (except for Corollary  which needs to be
reformulated), integrated density of states  and bounded
eigenfunctions .

Most importantly, classical Aubry duality ()
can be extended to this setting:
the operators
given by , where  have the property that if

Let us say that  is small if the family

Mathieu case).  In particular,  is small if
.  In
general, this notation is justified by Theorem 5.1 of which
shows that if  then
is
almost localized in the whole subexponential regime.

We will actually prove the following more general result in the
subexponential regime.

If  is small and  then the spectral measures of
are absolutely continous.

All the discussion below applies essentially unchanged to operators
with small  and .  Besides

Localization and reducibility

Localization and reducibility

Until the end of this section

In fact this argument shows that the set of energies for which the cocycle
is unbounded has Hausdorff dimension zero.  By Theorem , this set
contains the set of energies where the spectral measures (and the integrated
density of states) are not Lipschitz.

The exponential regime

Our approach to the exponential regime centers around the "parameter
exclusion" of energies to achieve control on the dynamics by consideration
of rational approximations.  A key difficulty is that our current
understanding does not lead to a uniform (over the phase space) control, but
merely an integrated control.  While the integrated control is
enough to obtain results
almost sure , it is certainly dangerous when trying
to obtain results for all .

Let us recall the idea of
to prove absolute continuity of the
integrated density of states.  There it is shown that for a
rational approximant, a large set of the spectrum can be selected where
we have the pointwise estimate
d dE N_,p/q (1+o(1)) d dE
N_,,
as long as  is exponentially close to ,
which easily implies that the absolutely continuous part of
has mass close to .

Let us recall the idea of
to prove absolute continuity of the

It seems a very hard problem to obtain pointwise estimates for the spectral
measures themselves, and we are still unable to show that, for
a large set of energies, the dynamics is under control for every
, that is, for the moment we can not prevent
d dE _,p/q, (1+) d dE
_,,.
Our approach will be to show that this can not happen for too many energies,
though which small set of energies must be excluded is not explicit
and could depend on .

d dE _,p/q,(1-) d dE
_,,for some other .  Then, integrating on , we conclude that if
for some phase  the total mass of the absolutely continuous part is
less than  (we recall that our spectral measure has total
mass )
then we can find another  for which the total mass of
the absolutely continuous part is greater than , which is clearly
impossible.

gap-labelling theorem states that if  belongs to a non-collapsed gap then
for some .  This
motivates the definition of the -th gap as the set of energies such that
.  With this definition a
gap could be collapsed, that is, it could reduce to a point.

motivates the definition of the -th gap as the set of energies such that
.  With this definition a
gap could be collapsed, that is, it could reduce to a point.

It is an interesting problem to get bounds on the size of the gaps.  The Dry
Ten Martini problem asks to show that in the case of the almost Mathieu
operator, the gaps are all non-collapsed.  An approach, successful in the
Liouville regime, is to obtain explicit lower bounds on the size of gaps, by
periodic approximations,.  But it is difficult to
extend this approach to the Diophantine case since the existing lower bounds
are exponentially small.

Here we will be concerned with upper bounds.  We will show that the -th
gap is indeed exponentially small whenever  is small and .

More on the subexponential regime

Quasiperiodic Schrodinger operators with small coupling

Let  be analytic and let
be the
quasiperiodic Schrodinger operator given by
.  The almost Mathieu
operator corresponds to the special case  for some .

A substantial part of
the theory of the almost Mathieu operator
can be extended to this more general setting.  Though we have
restricted our attention to the case of the
almost Mathieu operator to avoid distraction from the main result of this
paper, our analysis in the subexponential regime does extend to this larger
class, in parallel with the work of in the Diophantine regime.
The extension to the more general setting
is essentially automatic given the correct definitions, up to the proof of
the almost localization estimate (which is not a problem for us since it was
proved in for the subexponential regime).
